title: What do female soldiers do when they get their periods on the front lines? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well first of all, questions like this seem to indicate a mentality that there is a “front line” where combat is constantly occurring. Let’s get rid of that notion. There are areas with more activity and areas that generally have very low activity, but the idea of a front line doesn’t lend itself well to modern warfare. Let’s also make it clear that no matter where you are, combat is not the time to change a tampon. If you’re being shot at, that’s going to be pretty far from your mind. So whether this takes place on patrol or at a base, it’s going to happen during a period of downtime. Anyway, if you can defecate (which both men and women have to do), you can change a tampon. Some people find isolated locations to do it. Isolated may mean “hey guys I’m going on the other side of the truck for a moment” and generally people understand that means they need a moment of privacy or it could mean going into a tent, behind a tree, inside a latrine (if one was available), etc. Some people just don’t care. When you spend enough time with a small group of people (as tends to happen if you’re in an area where you can’t find that sort of privacy), you get comfortable with them. Men and women both may end up changing clothes, relieving themselves, or doing other things around a group of people that would never be considered acceptable in public back home.

Many of us get hormonal IUD’s (intrauterine devices). It is a form of birth control that releases progestogen from a small device inside the uterus. It is inserted by a doctor and provides birth control for 5 years. One of the common “side effects” is that one will not menstruate during this time. If one wishes to have children, the IUD can be removed by a doctor at any time. Having said that, I spent several years in the military before having this miraculous little device and having my period in the field was really not as big a deal as many people assume. Everyone goes to the bathroom. I would just also change my tampon when going to the washroom. If no bathrooms were available, I would either bury my feminine waste, in the same fashion that I would for a poop, or I would put it in a zip-lock that comes in our ration packs and dispose of it with the garbage from my ration at the next opportunity. At the end of the day, WAY easier than having to shave my face every morning and get haircuts every couple of weeks. Male soldiers are so high-maintenance ;)
